subNodes.conversationText: root

This one is not going to yield as easily as the first one did. Old locks sometimes dislike modern lockpicks, but I don't even see a lock. I wonder how long this door's been hiding here unopened?|***ga_jump_players-->String::ludosdoor_wp Int::1 Int::0 |
Many, many years, I'd say.  Probably since the days when there was no town, and the only thing that stood on this crag was Swordskeep.|***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False    String::gossam    |
[Examine the door more closely.]
[Running your fingers across the door, you realize that the words of a poem have been engraved into its surface.]
Look.  There are verses carved into the door.
Yes.  I can make them out.  It's a poem--it seems familiar to me, but I can't recall where I've seen it before.  It's--it's quite beautiful.
[Read the verses.]
[You read the verses and record them in your journal.]|***ga_journal-->String::Q_VERSES Int::1 Int::0 Int::0 Int::0 |
I wonder if Uncle Asterchord could tell us more about the poem or this door?  He knows more about Drawn Swords than anybody.|***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False    String::gossam    |
Clearly this is a riddle of some sort, but we'll need to do some investigating before we can figure out how it opens the door.  The trouble is that it doesn't read very much like a riddle at all.
Our investigation will have to be covert.  We do not want all of Drawn Swords to know that we plan to plunder the town's buried treasures.
Agreed, agreed.
[Ianth snorts, but she keeps studying the door with great interest.]
Well.  We will see.|***ga_journal-->String::Q_LUDOS    Int::1    Int::0    Int::0    Int::0    |

It's true that I like a fine poetic mystery myself.  But it is also true that we should not dally here among the dead for too much longer.  Lead on, <FirstName>!|***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False    String::gossam    |
[Shake your head and turn away.]|***ga_journal-->String::Q_LUDOS Int::1 Int::0 Int::0 Int::0 |
Let's look into the matter soon.  For now it seems there's little else to do here.|***ga_journal-->String::Q_LUDOS    Int::1    Int::0    Int::0    Int::0    |
Perhaps we ought to forget about this door altogether.  We have other concerns.
You are free to forget about the door, , but that doesn't mean I'm going to. Perhaps one night after you've dozed off at the Sword and Dragon--
Let's see what we can do about getting this open.

<color=green>[Bard/Lore] This is no riddle--at least on the surface.  I recognize it.  This is from "The Falcon and the Dove," an anonymous old ballad.|***gc_skill_dc-->NOT::False    Int::13    Int::20    ***gc_check_class-->NOT::False    Int::1    |
I should have realized you would recognize it. Good work. Now, how will knowing that get us in?|***ga_give_xp-->Int::100 Int::0 |
Let's leave it alone for now.
Too long a time for you, no doubt.
[The door remains unopened.]|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True String::Q_LUDOS String::!0 |
[Leave.]
[The door remains unopened.]
[Say the name "Ludos."] ||***ga_door_open-->String::ludos_door ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_LUDOS String::25 ||
